Claims for compensation
	Claims for compensation for riot damage etc
		Where— 
			a person’s property has been damaged, destroyed or stolen in the course ofa riot,
			the property is property in respect of which a claim may be made under thissubsection (see section 2(1)), and
			the property was not insured, or was not adequately insured, for thedamage, destruction or theft,
				the person may claim compensation from the appropriate local policing body.
		Where— 
			a person’s property has been damaged, destroyed or stolen in the course ofa riot,
			the property is property in respect of which a claim may be made under thissubsection (see section 2(2)), and
			an insurance company has (to any extent) met a claim by the person under apolicy of insurance in respect of the damage, destruction or theft,
			the insurance company may claim compensation from the appropriate localpolicing body.
		The appropriate local policing body is the local policing body which isresponsible for the police area in which the property was situated at the timeof the riot.
		A claim under this section must be made in accordance with regulations madeunder section 3.
		For the purposes of subsection (1)(c), property is not adequately insuredif—
			it is insured for an amount that is less than its value, or
			it is insured subject to an excess.
		In this Act, “riot” is to be construed in accordance with section 1 of thePublic Order Act 1986, but does not include a riot in any of the followingplaces—
			a prison, young offender institution or secure training centre;
			a hospital where persons are detained under Part 2 or 3 of the MentalHealth Act 1983;
			a removal centre, a short-term holding facility or pre-departureaccommodation (within the meaning given by section 147 of the Immigration andAsylum Act 1999).
	Property in respect of which claims may be made
		A claim may be made under section 1(1) only in respect of—
			a building,
			property falling within subsection (3), or
			a motor vehicle falling within any of the paragraphs of the Schedule (motorvehicles in respect of which claims may be made).
		A claim may be made under section 1(2) only in respect of—
			a building,
			property falling within subsection (3), or
			a motor vehicle falling within paragraph 4 of the Schedule (vehicle formingpart of stock in trade of a business).
		Property falls within this subsection if it is property (other than a motorvehicle) which at the time of the riot was situated—
			within a building,
			within the curtilage of a building, or
			on land being used for the purposes of a business carried on by theclaimant.
		The Secretary of State may by regulations—
			amend subsection (3);
			make provision about the meaning of terms used in that subsection.
		In this section—
			  * “building” includes— 
			a permanent or semi-permanent structure in the nature of a building (includinga caravan or houseboat), and
			a building in the course of construction;
				  * “motor vehicle” means a mechanically propelled vehicle intended or adapted for use on roads. 
	Regulations about claims procedure
		The Secretary of State must make regulations about the procedure for makinga claim under section 1.
		The regulations may include provision about—
			the appropriate person to make a claim (in particular where more than oneperson has an interest in property that has been damaged, destroyed orstolen), and
			the circumstances in which a single claim must cover a number of differentitems or types of property.
		The regulations may also include provision about—
			the person to whom a claim must be addressed;
			the time period within which a claim must be made;
			the details and evidence that must be submitted by the claimant;
			the time period within which details and evidence must be submitted;
			the submission of new evidence relating to a claim already made ordetermined.
		Regulations under subsection (3)(b) or (3)(d) must provide that—
			the time period within which a claim may be made ends no earlier than 42days from the date of the riot;
			the time period within which details and evidence must be submitted ends noearlier than 90 days from the date the claimant first made the claim.
		Regulations under subsection (3)(c) may include a requirement that anyestimates of the cost of repairs are to be prepared by contractors approved bythe Secretary of State or a local policing body.

The decision-maker
	The decision-maker on a claim
		The decision on a claim is to be made by the appropriate local policingbody, except where—
			the body delegates functions to another person in accordance withregulations made under subsection (2)(b), or
			the Secretary of State makes a direction under section 5(1)(b) (transfer ofclaims to the Secretary of State).
		The Secretary of State may make regulations allowing a local policing bodyto delegate to another person either or both of the following functions—
			dealing with procedural matters on a claim;
			making a decision on a claim.
		Regulations under subsection (2) may in particular make provision about—
			the persons to whom functions may be delegated,
			the types of claim in relation to which functions may be delegated (byreference to the nature of the property, the amount of the claim, the identityof the claimant or otherwise), and
			the payment and auditing of persons to whom functions are delegated.
	Transfer of claims to the Secretary of State
		The Secretary of State may direct a local policing body to transfer to theSecretary of State either or both of the following functions—
			dealing with procedural matters on a claim;
			making a decision on a claim.
		A direction under this section may relate to—
			all claims to the local policing body (whether made before or after thetime of the direction), or
			claims of a particular description.
		The Secretary of State may make a direction only if—
			riots have occurred in two or more police areas at or about the same time,
			a riot has moved from one police area to another, or
			a local policing body has requested the Secretary of State to make adirection in respect of claims that have been or may be made to it.
		Before making a direction in the circumstances described in subsection(3)(a) or (b), the Secretary of State must consult all local policing bodiesthat may be affected by the direction.
		The Secretary of State must publish a direction made under this section.
	Delegation of Secretary of State’s functions
		The Secretary of State may by regulations establish a body in connectionwith a direction under section 5 that the Secretary of State has made, or isconsidering making (the “riot claims bureau”).
		The regulations must provide that the principal function of the riot claimsbureau is to exercise either or both of the following functions on behalf ofthe Secretary of State—
			dealing with procedural matters on claims that have been transferred to theSecretary of State under section 5;
			making decisions on claims that have been transferred to the Secretary ofState under section 5.
		The regulations may make provision about—
			additional functions of the riot claims bureau;
			its status and constitution;
			the appointment of its members;
			the payment of remuneration and allowances to its members;
			the delegation of its functions to other persons;
			reporting and audit requirements;
			any other matters in connection with its operation and establishment.
		The Secretary of State may make regulations allowing the Secretary of Stateto delegate to another person either or both of the following functions—
			dealing with procedural matters on claims that have been transferred to theSecretary of State under section 5;
			making decisions on claims that have been transferred to the Secretary ofState under section 5.
		Regulations under subsection (3)(e) or (4) may in particular make provisionabout—
			the persons to whom functions may be delegated;
			the types of claim in relation to which functions may be delegated (byreference to the nature of the property, the amount of the claim, the identityof the claimant or otherwise), and
			the payment and auditing of persons to whom functions are delegated.

Decisions on claims
	Decision on validity of claim
		Where a person makes a claim under section 1, the decision-maker must firstdecide whether the claim is valid.
		A claim is valid if—
			it meets the conditions set out in—
			section 1(1)(a) to (c) (in the case of a claim under section 1(1)), or
			section 1(2)(a) to (c) (in the case of a claim under section 1(2)), and
			it is made in accordance with regulations under section 3.
		The Secretary of State may issue guidance on assessing the validity ofclaims, which may in particular include guidance on deciding whether propertywas damaged, destroyed or stolen in the course of a riot.
		Decision-makers must have regard to any guidance issued under subsection(3).
	Amount and payment of compensation
		If the decision-maker decides that a claim is valid, the decision-makermust then decide the amount of compensation, up to a maximum of £1 million perclaim (the “compensation cap”), that is fair and reasonable.
		The amount of compensation must reflect only the loss directly resultingfrom the damage, destruction or theft of the property, and in particular mustnot reflect any consequential loss resulting from it, except in thecircumstances described in subsection (3).
		Where a claimant’s home is rendered uninhabitable, the amount ofcompensation may reflect costs that the claimant incurs as a result of needingalternative accommodation.
		The Secretary of State may make regulations setting out—
			considerations that decision-makers must take into account in deciding theamount that reflects the claimant’s loss,
			considerations that decision-makers must take into account in deciding theamount of compensation payable as a result of a claimant needing alternativeaccommodation (and the regulations may include provision limiting the amountof time for which the costs of alternative accommodation may be claimed),
			other factors that may affect the amount of compensation to be paid, and
			the process for deciding and paying compensation.
		Regulations under subsection (4)(a) may also make provision about—
			the appropriate method for deciding the amount of compensation fordifferent types of property or different types of damage;
			the effect of the property being insured (or partially insured) on theamount of compensation.
		Regulations under subsection (4)(c) may in particular provide for—
			the amount of compensation to be increased to reflect costs or expensesincurred by the claimant in making a claim;
			the amount of compensation to be decreased to reflect the costs ofadministering the compensation scheme;
			the amount of compensation to be decreased, or for no compensation to beawarded, where the decision-maker considers this appropriate in view of anyact or omission of the claimant;
			a claim to be refused where the decision-maker believes that the claim, orany other claim made by the claimant, is fraudulent (to any extent).
		Regulations under subsection (4)(d) may in particular—
			provide for a claim to lapse where a claimant fails to provide the requireddetails or evidence;
			provide for interim payments to be made before a claim is finally decided;
			provide for the payment of compensation in instalments;
			provide that, instead of monetary compensation, the decision-maker mayarrange for repairs to be carried out on property that has been damaged, atthe expense of the appropriate local policing body;
			make provision about administrative requirements that must be satisfiedbefore any payment is made or repairs carried out.
		The appropriate local policing body must pay to the claimant the amount ofcompensation decided under this section.
		The Secretary of State may by regulations change the amount of thecompensation cap for the time being specified in subsection (1).
	Reviews and appeals
		The Secretary of State must make regulations giving a person affected by adecision under section 7 or 8—
			a right to request a review of the decision;
			a right to appeal against the decision, or any decision following a reviewby virtue of paragraph (a).

General
	Repeal of Riot (Damages) Act 1886 and consequential amendments etc
		The Riot (Damages) Act 1886 is repealed.
		In section 235 of the Merchant Shipping Act 1995 (liability for damage incase of plundered vessel)—
			in subsection (2)—
			for “compensation authority” substitute “appropriate local policing body”;
			for “Riot (Damages) Act 1886” substitute “Riot Compensation Act 2016”;
			after subsection (2) insert—
				“(2A)In subsection (2), “appropriate local policing body” has the same meaningas in the Riot Compensation Act 2016 (see section 1(3) of that Act).”
		Omit the following provisions—
			in the table in Schedule 9 to the Police Act 1964, the entry relating tothe Riot (Damages) Act 1886;
			section 10(1) of the Public Order Act 1986;
			paragraphs 9 to 11 of Schedule 7 to the Police Act 1996;
			paragraph 6 of Schedule 27 to the Greater London Authority Act 1999;
			paragraph 61 of Schedule 16 to the Police Reform and Social ResponsibilityAct 2011.
	Regulations 
		Regulations under this Act are to be made by statutory instrument.
		A statutory instrument containing regulations under this Act, other than—
			regulations under section 2(4) which restrict, or are capable ofrestricting, the categories of property in respect of which a claim may bemade,
			regulations under section 8(9) which reduce the amount of the compensationcap, and
			regulations under section 12(1) (commencement regulations),
				is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House ofParliament.
		A statutory instrument containing regulations described in subsection(2)(a) or (b) may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laidbefore each House of Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House.
		Regulations under this Act may—
			make different provision for different purposes;
			make different provision for different areas;
			make transitional, transitory or saving provision;
			make incidental, supplementary or consequential provision.
	Commencement, extent and short title
		Sections 1 to 10 and the Schedule come into force on whatever day or daysthe Secretary of State by regulations appoints.
		This section and section 11 come into force on the day on which this Act ispassed.
		This Act extends to England and Wales.
		This Act may be cited as the Riot Compensation Act 2016.
